study_metadata.title: Breast cancer prevention in community clinics: will low-income Latina patients participate in clinical trials?

inclusion_criteria: Potential eligibility for STAR trial (breast cancer risk factors, no prior exclusion)

study_context.setting: Community clinics in Washington, DC, and Virginia

intervention_details.name: Brief counseling plus print materials
intervention_details.description: Nonphysician-delivered education session and informational brochure
intervention_details.timing_and_duration: Single session, randomized by clinic day

primary.name: Intent to participate in STAR trial
primary.result: 72% overall; less with mention of side effects

strategies: Culturally and linguistically adapted educational intervention
recruitment_and_retention.summary: Latina women expressed high interest; intent dropped with mention of side effects.

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Latinas are interested in prevention trials, but side effect info reduces intention.
findings_and_implications.patient_knowledge: Moderate; knowledge higher for breast cancer than for trials
findings_and_implications.impact_on_underrepresented_groups: Addresses barriers for Latina, low-SES populations
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Education boosts interest, but side effect info deters; future work should focus on qualitative research.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Explore theory and context for preventive trial participation in Latinas.

notes: All participants Latina, low-income, mostly Spanish-speaking. Focused on intent, not actual enrollment.

study_metadata.title: Effects of disclosing financial interests on participation in medical research: A randomized vignette trial

recruitment_channels: Mailed letter from cardiologist, followed by telephone call

intervention_details.name: Financial disclosure statement in consent
intervention_details.description: Simulated informed consent describing (1) per capita payment, (2) equity ownership, or (3) no disclosure
intervention_details.timing_and_duration: Simulated consent read during follow-up phone call

primary.name: Willingness to participate
primary.result: Lower in equity group (mean 3.20) than per capita (3.51) or no disclosure (3.50)

secondary.name: Trust in investigator
secondary.result: Highest in per capita group, lowest in equity group

recruitment_and_retention.summary: Equity interest disclosures reduced willingness and trust more than per capita or no disclosure.

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Equity disclosures decrease willingness to participate and trust
findings_and_implications.informed_consent_quality: Negative comments and refusals more frequent with equity disclosures
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Financial disclosures should be carefully considered to avoid deterring participation.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Test impact in real trials, refine consent content.

notes: Vignette study, not a real trial. Sample mostly older, white men.

study_metadata.title: Cost effectiveness of screening for clinical trials by research assistants versus senior investigators

inclusion_criteria: DSM-IV dysthymic disorder, double depression, or chronic major depression
exclusion_criteria: History of psychosis, mania, or hypomania
Failed three antidepressant trials in past 3 years

recruitment_channels: Ads, radio, posters, word of mouth

intervention_details.name: Screening by research assistant
intervention_details.description: Telephone screening and referral for SCID interview

primary.name: Positive predictive value
primary.definition: Proportion of phone screen positives who were SCID positive

secondary.name: Screening cost per randomized subject
secondary.definition: Calculated using screener wage and interview time

strategies: Phone screening by RAs or SIs
recruitment_and_retention.summary: RAs equally effective and more cost-efficient than SIs for phone screening.

findings_and_implications.key_findings: No difference in predictive value, but RA screening is much cheaper
findings_and_implications.cost_effectiveness: RAs are 45% more cost-effective for trial screening
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Trained non-clinician staff can optimize recruitment resources.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Replicate findings in other settings/patient groups.

notes: First to examine cost/accuracy by screener type. Predominantly female sample.

study_metadata.title: Evaluating the benefits of a patient information video during the informed consent process
study_metadata.study_design: Randomized controlled trial (video vs written info)
study_metadata.ethical_approval: Women's College Hospital, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

SES.indicators: Education level (high school or lower vs college or higher)

inclusion_criteria: Attending antenatal care at participating clinics/hospitals
exclusion_criteria: Previous viewing of the Term PROM video

study_context.setting: Recruitment for a perinatal trial (Term PROM Study) evaluating induction vs expectant management for prelabour rupture of membranes
population_group: Pregnant women (not eligible for actual trial, to avoid interference)

intervention_details.name: Patient information video
intervention_details.description: A 10-minute professionally produced video describing the condition, study protocol, risks and benefits, participant and investigator testimonials, and invitation to participate.
intervention_details.timing_and_duration: Single exposure during clinic/office visit, followed by questionnaire

primary.name: Willingness for future participation
primary.definition: Proportion indicating they would participate in the Term PROM Study if eligible
primary.result: 61.9% video group vs 35.4% control at initial assessment (p=0.01); 56.1% vs 38.6% at 2–4 weeks (not statistically significant)

secondary.name: Knowledge retention
secondary.definition: Number (%) correctly answering ≥9/11 content questions about PROM and the study
secondary.result: No significant difference initially (95.2% vs 87.5%), but at 2–4 weeks, 87.8% video group vs 63.6% control (p=0.01)

secondary.name: Perceived importance of the study
secondary.definition: Rated on a 5-point scale; trend toward higher 'very important' in video group (not statistically significant, p=0.06)

recruitment_and_retention.summary: Video increased willingness to participate and improved information retention.
recruitment_and_retention.timeline: Enrolment June 28 to December 22, 1994; follow-up 2–4 weeks post-intervention

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Video information increased stated willingness to participate (significant at first assessment) and improved information retention at 2–4 weeks.
findings_and_implications.patient_knowledge: Improved in video group, particularly at follow-up.
findings_and_implications.impact_on_underrepresented_groups: Not specifically studied; sample was highly educated.
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Showing a patient information video can increase willingness to participate in clinical trials and may improve understanding of study details.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Future research should test effects in real-eligible patients, with different backgrounds and at different consent time points.

notes: No detailed breakdown of ethnicity. Majority highly educated. Used hypothetical participation, not actual trial eligibility.

study_metadata.title: Do messages of scarcity increase trial recruitment?
study_metadata.ethical_approval: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine Ethics Committee

study_context.setting: Recruitment for a mobile-based smoking cessation trial

intervention_details.name: Scarcity message via SMS
intervention_details.description: Text message stating there were only 300 places left in the trial, sent as reminder.
intervention_details.comparison_group: Standard reminder message without scarcity wording

primary.name: Consent rate within 3 days
primary.definition: Proportion of eligible individuals who texted consent to participate within 3 days

recruitment_and_retention.summary: Scarcity message increased consent rate compared to control
recruitment_and_retention.timeline: Recruitment messages sent June 1, 2009, outcome measured at 3 days

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Scarcity messages led to higher trial consent rates (OR 1.50, 95% CI 1.07–2.12)
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Scarcity messaging is a simple, effective way to boost recruitment in clinical trials.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: May be relevant to other recruitment-challenged trials.

notes: No breakdown of sex, SES, or ethnicity reported.

study_metadata.title: The impact of describing clinical trial treatments as new or standard
study_metadata.study_type: Experimental (survey with hypothetical clinical trial scenario)

inclusion_criteria: Adults (≥18 years) enrolled in further education and leisure courses in North Staffordshire

study_context.setting: Survey using hypothetical randomized trial leaflets (back-pain or arthritis scenarios)
recruitment_channels: In-class recruitment at adult education colleges

intervention_details.name: Description of treatments as new vs standard
intervention_details.description: Participants were randomly given a leaflet describing two trial treatments for back-pain or arthritis as either both 'standard' or one 'new' and one 'standard'.
intervention_details.timing_and_duration: Single written scenario, immediate survey response

primary.name: Treatment preference
primary.definition: Proportion expressing a preference for one trial treatment over the other
primary.result: Majority expressed no preference. In arthritis scenario, more people expressed a preference when one treatment was described as new (χ² = 5.44, p=0.031), but this was not specifically for the new treatment. In back-pain scenario, no significant difference.

secondary.name: Willingness to participate in RCT
secondary.definition: Whether preference affected willingness to participate in a hypothetical randomized trial
secondary.result: Participants with a preference for a treatment available outside the trial were less willing to participate (χ² = 23.3, p < 0.001). Preference for the new treatment was rare.

secondary.name: Interview themes
secondary.definition: Qualitative interviews explored reasoning behind preferences
secondary.result: Themes: (1) New/standard nature, (2) treatment similarity, (3) desperation, (4) condition severity, (5) information about treatments.

recruitment_and_retention.summary: No evidence that merely labeling a treatment 'new' induces preference for it over a standard; preferences more complex and context dependent.
recruitment_and_retention.timeline: Data collected in a single session per participant; interviews immediately after survey

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Describing a trial treatment as 'new' did not create a general preference for it. When a difference appeared (arthritis scenario), the trend was for participants to prefer the standard treatment. Willingness to join an RCT reflected rational choices about treatment access.
findings_and_implications.informed_consent_quality: Preferences may be influenced by context and prior beliefs, not by labeling alone.
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Labeling a treatment as new does not, by itself, drive preference. Preferences for new or standard may depend on context, condition severity, and other factors.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Design of trial materials should not assume that 'new' implies preference; further research should explore real-patient contexts and other variables influencing preferences.

tables_and_figures: Tables 1–5: Preference frequencies, scenario details, willingness by preference, qualitative coding
notes: Survey sample from adult education classes, mostly female, mean age ~31. No medical patients included.

study_metadata.title: Recruitment of Hispanic women to the Women’s Health Initiative: the case of Embajadoras in Arizona
study_metadata.study_design: Randomized controlled intervention (trained vs untrained lay advocates)

inclusion_criteria: Current participant in the Women’s Health Initiative (WHI) trial in Arizona
Minimum number of social contacts (for advocate selection)
Positive attitude toward the study (for advocate selection)

study_context.setting: Recruitment to the Women’s Health Initiative (WHI), a large multi-center prevention trial targeting postmenopausal women

intervention_details.name: Embajadoras (trained Hispanic lay advocates)
intervention_details.description: Hispanic WHI participants received 6 hours of training on advocacy and communication, then met quarterly to encourage advocacy and were given brochures to distribute.
intervention_details.comparison_group: Untrained Hispanic participants (received brochures only, no training); Untrained Anglo participants (received brochures only, no training)
intervention_details.timing_and_duration: 18 months; five quarterly meetings for trained group

primary.name: Referral and enrollment success
primary.definition: Proportion of women in each group who referred or enrolled any new participant
primary.result: Embajadoras: 39.3% referred, 28.6% enrolled; Hispanic controls: 7.7% referred, 0% enrolled; Anglo controls: 23.8% referred, 4.8% enrolled. Embajadoras were 7.8 times more likely than Hispanic controls to refer (OR 7.76, 95% CI 1.52–39.62, p<0.01); enrollment difference p<0.001.

secondary.name: Brochure distribution
secondary.definition: Mean number of brochures requested/distributed per participant
secondary.result: Embajadoras distributed significantly more brochures than controls (mean 32.9 vs 19.2 vs 11.4, p<0.001)

recruitment_and_retention.summary: Trained Hispanic lay advocates (Embajadoras) were more successful in recruiting and enrolling new Hispanic women than untrained Hispanic or Anglo women.
recruitment_and_retention.timeline: Intervention ran for 18 months with quarterly check-ins

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Culturally relevant, trained lay advocacy can boost recruitment and enrollment of Hispanic women to clinical trials. Simply providing brochures is less effective.
findings_and_implications.impact_on_underrepresented_groups: Effective strategy for Hispanic (minority) recruitment; not directly tested in other minority groups.
findings_and_implications.cost_effectiveness: Not directly evaluated; training required moderate resources.
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Lay advocacy with ongoing contact and support is effective for minority recruitment. More research is needed on factors influencing successful referral-to-enrollment conversion.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Future studies should test this approach in other populations and settings; should explore barriers in converting referrals to enrollments.

tables_and_figures: Table 2: Comparison of advocacy success among study groups
notes: Participants selected for social network size and positive attitudes; some small sample sizes; age range 50–79 years; all female.

study_metadata.title: Presenting clinical trial information: a comparison of methods

study_context.objective: To compare the effects of audio tape vs. interactive computer program on trial information understanding and entry intention.
study_context.study_design_and_setting: Randomized study among radiation therapy patients at Sunnybrook Health Science Centre.
study_context.population_group: Adult cancer patients receiving radiation therapy (excluding brain/eye tumors, leukemia, HIV-related Kaposi's sarcoma).

inclusion_criteria: Not in a current clinical trial

interventions.name: Interactive computer program
interventions.description: Participants used a HyperCard-based program to navigate clinical trial information
interventions.details: Allowed participant control of sequence and pace of learning

interventions.name: Audio tape
interventions.description: Participants listened to a standardized recorded explanation of a hypothetical trial

comparison: Audio tape vs. interactive computer teaching formats

recruitment_and_retention_strategies.effectiveness_summary: Computer group showed more positive attitude toward trial entry; no difference in understanding or satisfaction
recruitment_and_retention_strategies.general_recruitment_challenges_and_conte: Addressed low comprehension and decision-making capacity in trial consent

findings.patient_accrual: 100 patients enrolled (60% of those eligible agreed)
findings.patient_knowledge: No significant difference in understanding between groups
findings.informed_consent_quality: Some refusers had high understanding but still declined
findings.underrepresented_group_impact: Women were more likely to refuse
findings.conclusion: Interactive formats may increase trial acceptability; understanding is not format-dependent
findings.implication_for_future_research: Future studies should include actual trial decisions and account for respondent sex

notes: Focus on hypothetical trial entry; more research needed for real clinical settings. Baseline trust and demographics not fully reported.

study_metadata.title: Blinding decreased recruitment in a prevention trial of postmenopausal hormone therapy
study_metadata.study_design: Randomized comparison (blind vs nonblind group allocation)
study_metadata.ethical_approval: Committee of Medical Ethics, Tallinn, Estonia; University of Tampere, Finland

exclusion_criteria: Current or previous breast or uterine cancer
History of DVT, PE, stroke, meningioma, porphyria, endometriosis, recent MI or hepatitis
Desire for PHT or plans to move

study_context.setting: Primary prevention trial for postmenopausal hormone therapy in Estonia
recruitment_channels: Postal questionnaire and information leaflet sent to general population

intervention_details.name: Randomization to blind (placebo-controlled) vs nonblind (open-label) group
intervention_details.description: Eligible women were randomized to receive invitation for a blind (PHT vs placebo) or nonblind (PHT vs no treatment) trial group. Study and recruitment procedures identical except for blinding.

primary.name: Recruitment rate
primary.definition: Percentage of eligible and interested women enrolled after receiving group-specific invitation
primary.result: 37% recruited in blind group (95% CI 35–39%) vs 48% in nonblind group (95% CI 46–49%)—a 30% higher recruitment rate in the nonblind group; absolute difference 10.3% (95% CI 7.4–13.2%, p<0.001)

secondary.name: Attrition at different recruitment stages
secondary.definition: Percent lost at various steps (did not attend clinical exam, ineligible, lost interest)
secondary.result: Most loss was failure to attend initial clinical exam (49% blind, 40% nonblind); remaining losses due to ineligibility or lost interest.

secondary.name: Reasons for joining
secondary.definition: Self-reported reasons for participating, via 1-year follow-up survey
secondary.result: Similar in both groups: main reasons were free medical exam, desire to help research, help for menopause; few cited free drugs.

strategies: Blinded vs nonblinded allocation in invitation materials
Personalized invitation, follow-up by phone and letter, in-person clinical exam
recruitment_and_retention.summary: Blinding (use of placebo group) decreased recruitment compared to nonblind, open-label design.
recruitment_and_retention.timeline: Recruitment 1998–2001; 1-year follow-up data on reasons for joining

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Nonblinded design increased recruitment by ~30% compared to a blinded (placebo-controlled) design in a long-term prevention trial.
findings_and_implications.informed_consent_quality: No major difference in satisfaction with information provided.
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Allowing participants to know their treatment arm (nonblind) may substantially improve recruitment in preventive trials.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Blinding may hinder recruitment in long-term prevention trials. Future studies should examine generalizability and trade-offs between bias reduction and feasibility.

notes: Population-based approach; substantial attrition at each stage; trial context was postmenopausal hormone therapy, a preventive intervention.

study_metadata.title: Publicity does not increase recruitment to falls prevention trials: the results of two quasi-randomized trials

inclusion_criteria: Registered with participating general practitioner in North and West Yorkshire
At least one fall in the previous 12 months

study_context.setting: Primary care recruitment for falls prevention randomized trial
recruitment_channels: Postal recruitment packs sent via GP practices

intervention_details.name: Publicity via newspaper article in recruitment pack
intervention_details.description: Participants received a photocopied local newspaper article about the trial with their standard study invitation materials. In study 2, a more 'upbeat' article was tested.
intervention_details.timing_and_duration: Single inclusion in initial recruitment pack

primary.name: Recruitment rate
primary.definition: Percentage of recipients recruited to the main trial
primary.result: Study 1: 3.25% publicity vs 3.16% control (no significant difference, p=0.80); Study 2: 4.15% upbeat publicity vs 3.94% standard publicity (no significant difference, p=0.75)

secondary.name: Response rate
secondary.definition: Percentage of recipients who responded (agreed to participate or not)
secondary.result: Study 1: 4.55% publicity vs 4.32% control; Study 2: 5.46% upbeat vs 5.03% standard; neither difference statistically significant

strategies: Inclusion of media publicity articles in recruitment materials
recruitment_and_retention.summary: No evidence that publicity via newspaper articles improved recruitment or response rates.
recruitment_and_retention.timeline: Study 1: 4,488 packs sent; Study 2: 2,745 packs sent after first wave; each analyzed after initial mailing.

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Including newspaper articles in recruitment packs had no significant effect on recruitment or response rates in two large trials.
findings_and_implications.cost_effectiveness: Publicity is inexpensive but did not improve yield.
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Simple media publicity is unlikely to enhance recruitment for clinical trials among older adults.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Researchers should evaluate other strategies; future work could target different populations or settings.

tables_and_figures: Figure 1: Flowchart of responses and recruitment (study 1)
Figure 2: Flowchart of responses and recruitment (study 2)
notes: Large sample size; allocation via alternation (quasi-randomized); possible contamination if some control participants saw newspaper articles independently.

study_metadata.title: Telephone reminders are effective in recruiting nonresponding patients to randomized controlled trials

inclusion_criteria: Diagnosis of nonsevere psychological problems or musculoskeletal pain

study_context.setting: Recruitment for a randomized trial comparing standard care vs solution-focused follow-up among long-term sick-listed employees
population_group: Sick-listed employees, general adult working-age population

intervention_details.name: Telephone reminder to nonresponders
intervention_details.description: Nonresponders to an initial invitation letter were randomly assigned to receive either an attempted telephone reminder or no further contact.
intervention_details.timing_and_duration: Telephone contact attempted 2–3 weeks after initial letter; up to 3–4 attempts at different times of day

primary.name: Recruitment rate among nonresponders (intention to phone analysis)
primary.definition: Percentage of nonresponders subsequently recruited after intervention
primary.result: 12.1% recruited with telephone reminder vs 4.5% with no reminder (p=0.003; OR 2.89, 95% CI 1.42–5.90)

secondary.name: Overall recruitment rate (intention to recruit analysis)
secondary.definition: Total percentage recruited among all initially invited

secondary.name: Number needed to phone
secondary.definition: How many nonresponders must be phoned to recruit one additional participant

recruitment_and_retention.summary: Systematic telephone follow-up increased recruitment among nonresponders.
recruitment_and_retention.timeline: Letters sent from Feb 2002 to Feb 2003; phone calls made 2–3 weeks after letter

findings_and_implications.key_findings: Telephone reminders significantly increased recruitment among nonresponders in an RCT.
findings_and_implications.cost_effectiveness: Phoning is resource-intensive but more efficient than expanding recruitment sites.
findings_and_implications.authors_conclusions: Whenever feasible, systematic telephone reminders should be considered to increase uptake in RCTs.
findings_and_implications.implications_for_future_research: Future work should assess cost-effectiveness and standardize phone call approaches; consider after-hours calling.

notes: Randomization occurred at initial letter stage; some baseline differences existed between intervention/control in nonresponder group. No postal reminders used.
